data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) was formed in April 2020 as a result of the merger of three acute hospitals across Essex (Southend University Hospital, Basildon University Hospital, and Broomfield Hospital) and a number of smaller community hospitals. The MSE Trust as a single acute Provider organisation serves a population of  million people across Essex with an overarching vision of “One Team, Working Together” across three hospital sites.

The MSE Trust is committed to safeguarding all vulnerable people who access services across the organisation. This safeguarding strategy sets out the strategic approach to strengthening our arrangements for safeguarding across the Trust over the next two years whilst working in partnership with other key stakeholders and in line with national guidance.

This Strategy has been developed at a point where the MSE organisation has been established for one year, and an internal review of safeguarding policy and procedures has commenced. Alignment of safeguarding practice is progressing to an MSE approach, and areas for safeguarding development are being identified and prioritised.
Scope
Our safeguarding Vision
2.1.1 Our vision is simple - we will strive to ensure that safeguarding is at the heart of everything we do.
Our ambition is clear-
2.2.1 All children, young people and adults who pass through our doors should feel safe in our care and feel confident that our staff will identify any vulnerability and take action appropriately.

2.2.2 There will be a whole organisational approach to safeguarding and promoting the welfare  of  children,  young  people  and  adults.  This  will  be  embedded  as  core business across the organisation.
2.2.3 There  will  be  robust  reporting  and  governance  arrangements  to  support  the safeguarding agenda in place, and across the system.

2.2.4 We will be a learning organisation. Examples of good safeguarding practice and the learning from situations where we could have done better will enhance and shape the delivery of the safeguarding service across the MSE.

2.2.5 The  patient  and  carer's  experience  and  feedback  will  influence  safeguarding practice across the Trust. We will actively seek the voice of the child and vulnerable adults accessing our services.
2.2.6 We will ensure that all Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust employees are aware of their shared responsibility to safeguard adults, young people and children. This

may be when the adult, child, or young person is a patient themselves, an unborn, a visitor, a patient's child, or an adult presenting to an adult service. The term ‘safeguarding' covers everything that assists a child, young person or adult at risk to live a life that is free from abuse and neglect and which enables them to retain independence, well-being, dignity and choice.

2.2.7 We will ensure a ‘Think Family' approach to care and intervention across all services is promoted and embedded in practice. This approach will foster a more robust and holistic assessment, intervention and provision of support for all patients and families, enabling both adults and children's services to join up where appropriate around the needs of the family.
2.2.8 We will provide a service which is committed to looking after all patients across all vulnerable groups with respect to their individual needs and requirements as defined in the Care Act 2014.

2.2.9 We will continue to support the changing landscape of safeguarding and protect and champion those who are vulnerable, at risk, abused, missing or exploited or trafficked, and we will continue to support staff with the complexity of practice and decision making required to safeguard children and vulnerable adults.

2.2.10 This Safeguarding strategy and the strategy work plan is built around and reflects the values identified by Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust for achieving high quality safe healthcare for our patient population:
Professional and Accountable- Safe
Working Together –Excellent
Care with Compassion-Caring

2.2.11 Across the MSE there will be a whole organisational approach to safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and adults which will be embedded across all of the divisions and services provided and in every aspect of the Trust's work. This Strategy  reflects  the  significant role  that  the  MSE  safeguarding  has  to  play in educating, developing and supporting Trust staff to recognise and report suspected harm and abuse.

We are committed to continually evaluating and improving the standards of safeguarding expertise and knowledge across the organisation, and our ambition is that this Safeguarding Strategy will be embraced by all MSE Trust staff.

The MSE Trust aims to ensure that no act or omission by the organisation puts patients at risk of abuse or neglect, and that rigorous systems are in place to proactively safeguard children, young people and adults. This strategy is underpinned by law, national safeguarding legislation and guidance, and by the statutory safeguarding duties and responsibilities required of all NHS organisations.

A Think Family approach refers to the steps taken by children's, young people's and adult's practitioners to identify wider family needs which extend beyond the individual they are supporting.
They are clinically-led statutory NHS bodies responsible for the planning and commissioning of health care services for their local area

Safeguarding Children Partnerships provide the safeguarding arrangements under which the safeguarding partners and relevant agencies work together to coordinate their safeguarding services and respond to the needs of children in their area. The partnership is responsible for commissioning and publishing local child safeguarding practice reviews and providing scrutiny to ensure the effectiveness of the safeguarding arrangements.

The overarching purpose of an SAB is to help and safeguard adults with care and support needs by assuring itself that local safeguarding arrangements are in place as defined by the Care Act 2014 and statutory guidance. The Board leads adult safeguarding arrangements across its locality and oversee and coordinate the effectiveness of the safeguarding work of its member and partner agencies.

Sets out a clear legal framework for how local authorities and other parts of the system should protect adults at risk of abuse or neglect. The local authorities must lead the multi-agency local adult safeguarding system that seeks to prevent abuse and neglect and stop it quickly when it happens.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
The MSE will demonstrate compliance with the requirements of:
The Care Act 2014
The Health & Social Care Act 2012
The Mental Capacity Act 2005
The Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards 2009
The Human Rights Act 1998
The Equality Act 2010, and Vulnerable Groups Act, 2006
The Prevent Duties
Liberty protection Safeguards

The Children Act 1989 and 2004 which places a duty on all providers of services, to ensure that in exercising its functions, robust arrangements are in place to safeguard and protect the wellbeing of children.
The Learning Disability Improvement Standards for NHS trusts 2019
And all the relevant guidance and legislation which cover contextual safeguarding.

Safeguarding is a Care Quality Commission standard (CQC) and a duty at the centre of our daily business. Specific CQC outcomes are reflected in in this strategy and the safeguarding work streams and action plans:
CQC Outcome : Safeguarding people who use services from abuse. The objective being that, people should be protected from abuse and staff should respect their human rights

CQC Outcome 4: Care and welfare of people who use services. The objective being that, people should get safe and appropriate care that meets their needs and supports their rights. Included in both outcomes are the implementation of the Mental Capacity Acts and the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards and the implementation of the new Liberty Protection Safeguards.
CQC Regulation : Fundamental Standard Safeguarding service users from abuse and improper treatment (Health and Social Care Act 2008 (Regulated Activities) Regulations 2014: Regulation 13)

In response to CQC standards the MSE will ensure that those who use our services are safeguarded and that staff are suitably skilled and supported to carry out their safeguarding function and responsibility.

The Safeguarding of Vulnerable Adults' Young People and Children in the NHS- Accountability and Assurance Framework (updated 2019) sets out the safeguarding roles, duties and responsibilities of all NHS organisations and is integral to the safeguarding work carried out within the MSE Trust.

The framework identifies and clarifies how relationships between health and other systems work at both strategic and operational levels to safeguard children and young people and adults at risk of harm of abuse, and sets out the underpinning

legal framework for safeguarding as it relates to the various NHS organisations in order to support them in discharging their statutory requirements to safeguard children and adults. The framework confirms the responsibilities of the MSE and its individual staff in this regard, and this is promoted across the organisation through all activities; making it clear that safeguarding is everyone's business and responsibility.

This Safeguarding Strategy supports and reflects national safeguarding guidance and the local Southend Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding and Child Protection Procedures for Children and the SET Guidance for Safeguarding Adults. The strategy and action plans additionally reflect and support the three Local Safeguarding Partnerships (children) and the Safeguarding Adults Boards priorities for safeguarding.

The MSE is committed to a model of continual improvement of safeguarding practice and this strategy and the action plans support the local accountability and assurance structures incorporating the Safeguarding Partnerships (Children) and the Safeguarding Adult Boards (SAB). The MSE also works closely with the Clinical Commissioning Groups covering Mid Essex, Southend, Basildon and Thurrock to provide safeguarding assurance.

All health care providers are required to have effective arrangements in place to safeguard vulnerable children and adults. This strategy and the strategy work plan provides the framework for demonstrating evidence of our compliance which include:

Senior management commitment and accountability to ensure that staff are competent to carry out their responsibilities and creating an environment where staff feel able to raise concerns and feel supported in safeguarding responsibilities (Francis Report, 2014)

An ethos of safeguarding being everyone's responsibility and a culture of listening to children and vulnerable adults to take into account their views and wishes in individual care and in the development of services

Effective training of all staff, commensurate with their role and in accordance with the Intercollegiate Document for Safeguarding Children (2019) , and the Intercollegiate Document for Safeguarding Adult ( 2018)
Effective supervision arrangements for staff, commensurate to their role and function
Developing and promoting a learning culture to ensure continuous improvement
Effective interagency working and information sharing with partner agencies
Safer recruitment procedures in place
A suite of safeguarding policies and procedures that support local multi- agency safeguarding procedures
Named Professionals in post and commensurate with Intercollegiate Guidance

Strategy Action Plan

The Safeguarding strategy is supported by a strategy action plan for children and maternity and one for adult services. The safeguarding priorities will be translated into objectives, actions and measurable outcomes through the action plans.

The action plans will be evolving live documents, and will be used over the next 24 months to develop, direct, and drive forward our safeguarding priorities, to increase the quality of safeguarding across the MSE, and to respond to and progress the safeguarding agenda across the MSE. The action plans will be reviewed and updated on a two monthly basis by the Associate Director for Safeguarding and the Deputy Associate Director and the Safeguarding Named Nurses and Leads.

Progress of the action plans will be reported through the MSE Integrated Adult and Children Safeguarding Committee which will provide an arena for monitor, review, challenge and for escalation of issues arising from the strategy work plan. Unresolved areas of concern will be escalated to the Integrated Governance Committee and Trust Board.
